content.content:
[]>narrator: Black. Cloth. Bagged over your face. Difficulty moving.
[]>narrator: Shit predicament.
[]>sophie{sophie-emotion|neutral,heather-emotion|neutral}: Heather, I bring forth to you but one request: <mp>Obedience.
[]>sophie:A woman's voice. Enunciated. Raspy, yet warm. <mp>Strong enough to calcify your movement. If you even were squirming much before. 
[]>narrator: Any of the thousand questions screaming through your mind do not make it outwards. <mp>Mouth gagged. Taped shut? Something like that.
[]>sophie: You learn quickly, thank you. <mp>You will get to express yourself shortly.
[]>narrator: Your arms feel bolted down.
[]>narrator: After a brief silence, the tarp is lifted.
[]>narrator: You're greeted to a dingy room. Dying incandescent bulb humming overhead. Air heavy with mold.

[]>narrator: When your eyes adjust, the figure stops being a morast-like blob.
[]>narrator: The light is directed at the table between.
[]>narrator: Your arms - are - bolted down.
[]>narrator: Her eyes pierce weight on you as if sensing your fear.
[]>sophie: More presently, I can see your eyes jitter like there's no tomorrow honey.
[]>narrator: What the fuck.
[]>heather: What the fuck.
[]>sophie: What the fuck indeed.
[]>sophie: Do not worry, I am no psychic. It is simply a matter of you not being the first one in that chair- By a wide margin.
[]>sophie: And if you cooperate, you won't have to die, soiling it - And I won't have to clean your half-digested breakfast out of this room. Is that not a win-win, honey?
[]>narrator: ...
[]>sophie: I asked you a question. Are we clear on what the stakes are for incooperativeness?
[]>narrator: Glacially, you begin to hint at a nod.
[]>narrator: After a while of signaling your understanding, the woman in front of you continues.
[]>sophie: Good. Then let us begin with negotiations.
[]>narrator: The rag keeping your mouth shut is loosened. Not cut free. <mp>You breathe in.

[]>sophie: For now, all you need to know is that you inherited some debts.
[]>sophie: You will need to reimburse them, to me.
[]>sophie: As you have already ascertained, you are not to leave this place, for now. First we ought to come to an agreement.
[]>sophie:You are not a person anymore. You belong to me.
[]>sophie: And to make you aware of this fact in perpetuitity, I will send you home with a slight modification to what used to be [i]your[/i] body.
[]>narrator: She accentuates that last part with a finger pointed between your eyes. <mp>Your heart rate quickens. Moreso than before.

[]>sophie: Look down at your hand. In a few minutes time it will not have all five fingers anymore.
[]>narrator: You can't think. Pulse drowning out your thoughts. <mp>The only thing cutting through is her commandeering tone.
[]>sophie: Pick a finger for me to sever.
[]>narrator: Words are difficult to produce at the moment.
[]>sophie: And no worries about going nonverbal, honey. Just stick out the finger you want to say goodbye to the most.
[]>narrator: Fuckfuckfuckfuckfuckingfuckshitfuck
[]>narrator: You flex your fingers. Get her to let you keep all of them. Somehow. <mp>Please.
[]>sophie: If you fail to decide, I will do it for you. <mp>I need another middle finger for my collection. Something to think about, is it not?

[]>narrator: Quickly, you stick out your index finger to protect your middle one. You need it to tell people to fuck off... <mp>And to... <mp>No you stupid horny brain what is wrong with you.
[]>narrator: But you also need... Fuck it- You need them all.

[]>sophie: Oh, no fingers? Would you rather we cut at the wrist?
[]>narrator:You freeze up-
[]>sophie:Again, in about ten seconds I will drive an axe through your wrist. <mp>Do you want to go home with a stump?
[]>narrator:Fuckfuckfuck.
[]>sophie: ...And if you think that I will not follow through, you have still failed to grasp the gravity of the situation.
[]>narrator: She motions to someone ...Or something... Behind you.

[]>narrator: Frantically, you splay your hand back out, wiggling your fingers so that they fittingly look like they're in their death throes.
[]>narrator: You slam your palm down.
[]>sophie: No need for excessive force.
[]>narrator: Your heart is bursting now. Head slumps.

[]>narrator: You stretch out your index finger again. <mp>Reconsider. <mp>R<call:show_cg,hand_ring,0,true>ing finger. Final decision.
[]>narrator: You look up from your hand. The walls are tiled. A few of them cracked.
[]>sophie: Look at me.
[]>narrator:You look at her.
[]>sophie: Your final choice?
[]>narrator: You keep eye contact. Motionless.
[]>sophie: So be it.
[]>narrator: Her eyes flick a spark up to the girl that has been the machine up and down your hand for this entire process..

[]>narrator:The handaxe hits your bone. <mp>After several chops it finally snaps.
[]>narrator: You expunge noises you never thought possible. <mp>Blood-curdling panicked shriek. <mp>This is horrible and fucked and is that really your finger on the table now? It still feels attached, by virtue of phantom limb.
[]>sophie: Like I said, we do not half-ass shit. <lc>We have medical staff on site. This will be taken care off, then you will be brought home. <mp>More info in the morning.
[]>narrator:You are a sobbing, hyperventilating mess.
[]>narrator:Breathing requires so much oxygen that you might just suffocate in this small room. <mp>Barely any air makes it through the gag.

[]>sophie:I hope I do not have to spell it out that you are not to tell anyone about this in the meantime. 
[]>sophie:If you try to run away, you will be back here in no time.
[]>sophie:Less gently then. 
[]>sophie:We found you once. And will again. If this were to be the case, I would not be satisfied with one finger. And you sure as hell would not get a say in the matter, got it?
[]>sophie:You will find more info in your mailbox by tomorrow noon. 
[]>sophie:Call sick into work for the rest of the week and then I will make sure you are well taken care of. <mp>That is not a euphemism.

[]>narrator: The next morning, your alarm blares you awake after much too little sleep.
[]>narrator: You use your landline to call into work and say your mom died and you need a few days of bereavement.
[]>narrator: This close after waking up you still don't have feeling everywhere in your body. Holding a phone with one less finger is a challenge however.
[]>narrator: When you put the receiver down, it stings more. The driver left you with ibuprofen. You slam 1.5times the daily recommended dosage to make it through the process of waking up.

[]>narrator:When noon comes, you check your mailbox.
[]>sophie{sophie-emotion|invisible}:[i]Heather.<lc>[i]Thank you for staying home today. <lc>[i]As a reward, I think it only appropriate to extend that trust and ask you kindly to visit me again tonight at 9 pm.
[]>sophie:[i]Attached is a map printout and the address you need to go to.<lc>[i]It should give you no trouble to navigate here.
[]>sophie:[i]Warm hugs <3
[]>heather:...
[]>heather:I...
[]>heather:Can I quickly say that this is like... beyond fucked?
[]>heather:And why would I need a printout? <mp>It's not as if...
[]>heather:...
[]>narrator:Is your PC still here?
[]>heather{heather-emotion|shock}:AND WHAT ABOUT MY PHONE?
[]>narrator:You frantically pat down your pockets and your stump stings. <mp>Nothing. <lc>You... [i]attempt[/i] to dart into your bedroom. You sometimes bump into furniture you didn't really see.

[]>narrator{heather-emotion|neutral}: The steps through your apartment feel like you're walking on cotton. <lc>Everything is kind of numb. You're not in the mood for putting on music - Or doing anything, really. <lc>Through this veil clouding your conscious, you hazily make your way to your bedroom desk.
[]>narrator: Oh right, that's still there... Apparently.
[]>narrator: In your bedroom you do find... Your PC. 
[]>narrator: ...It turns on.
[]>narrator: ...It doesn't connect to any web pages.
[]>narrator: When you open the default text editor... A desktop notification disturbs your haze.
[]>narrator: [code]Thinking of leaving a manifesto?
[]>narrator: [code]Don't.
[]>narrator{heather-emotion|sad}: You shut the PC down again.
[]>narrator: The late spring air makes your nose tingle.
[]>narrator: You don't know what to do, so you rot on the couch for a while. If only you had your flip phone here, those free games would be a godsend right now.
[]>narrator: Until the evening, sleep never graces you for more than a few minutes.

[]>sophie{sophie-emotion|neutral,heather-emotion|neutral}: Heather! I am delighted to see you made it back. <mp>Thank you so much for coming, darling.
[]>narrator: As if on autopilot, your legs carried you back here. The second story of some dense high-rise cement block. Close to the industry outskirts, these apartments are more spartan than many of their downtown equivalents. The walls reek of smoke.
[]>narrator: The room is... Largely the same. Your dried blood from yesterday has crusted into the tabletop.
[]>narrator: Now that you're free in your movement you can spot at least three other girls- guards, presumably.
[]>narrator: Silent. Stoic. Staring into nothing.
[]>sophie: Why won't you have a seat? We are just here to talk afterall.
[]>narrator: She is not relinquishing her stare towards you.
[]>narrator{heather-emotion|sad}: Wavering, you trod into the chair you were bolted to yesterday. <mp>You keep your hands in your lap. <mp>Head down.
[]>sophie: Can you look at me?
[]>narrator: You can.
[]>narrator{heather-emotion|neutral}: You do.
[]>sophie: Thanks.
[]>sophie: So, let us get to it then.
[]>sophie: Did you bring your phone?
[]>heather: ...
[]>heather{heather-emotion|neutral}: Phone?
[]>sophie: Yes, why not?
[]>heather: It wasn't there. Couldn't find it.

[]>sophie: Did you check your mailbox before you left? I am sure it should have been delivered to you over the course of the afternoon.
[]>heather: ...
[]>sophie: Well?
[]>heather: ...Didn't.
[]>sophie: Can you repeat that for me?
[]>heather: I said I didn't check my mailbox.
[]>sophie: Thank you, hun. What a shame. But no matter, you will get all you need from me.
[]>heather: ..?
[]>sophie: You see, I want you to get comfortable with the type of work I conduct. <mp>It often requires a delicate hand... To deliver these types of goods.
[]>narrator: Cigarette drag.
[]>heather: ...
[]>narrator: Smoke towards your face.
[]>sophie: For there are many vices out there. Everyone has one. And I make sure that a special kind of reject always gets their special kind of fix.
[]>narrator: You're not sure if you should even talk back. 
[]>sophie: Too flowery?
[]>heather: ...
[]>sophie: ...
[]>heather: ...It's fine.
[]>sophie: I understand, it is a stressful situation for you, sitting across from me.
[]>sophie: But I assure you, I mean you no harm.
[]>sophie: But to get to the point: I need you to make a delivery for me.
[]>heather: ...
[]>sophie: A position on this small supply chain recently became vacated, and I thought it was the perfect opportunity for you to start paying off your debt.
[]>narrator: Whatever the fuck that actually is.
[]>sophie: I know you did not rack it up, Heather. But you were the best available next-of-kin, so to say.
[]>heather: What do you mean?

[]>sophie: Anna.
[]>heather: College-Anna?
[]>sophie:The one you have been developing a crush for for a while now, yes.
[]>sophie:Those feelings were mutual.
[]>heather:...
[]>heather{heather-emotion|sad}:...Were.
[]>sophie:I apologize for being the bearer of bad news, I am afraid.
[]>heather:What...
[]>sophie: She had not responded in a few days, correct?
[]>heather: Yeah...
[]>sophie: Well, now you know.
[]>heather: You killed her...
[]>sophie: I would not go that far.
[]>heather: Oh yeah, then someone else iced her. Got it.
[]>heather{heather-emotion|crying}: Fuck off.
[]>narrator: Your forehead meets the tabletop.
[]>narrator: In silence, you sob.
[]>narrator: Chair scrapes.
[]>narrator: Hand on your back.
[]>heather: Don't touch me.
[]>narrator: She recedes her hand.
[]>narrator: You cry more.
[]>narrator: And more.
[]>narrator: And when your tears have not run dry quite yet, you shakily ask.
[]>heather: I'll be your drug mule?
[]>sophie: For the time being.
[]>heather: ...
[]>sophie: I am sorry, Heather.
[]>heather: ...
[]>heather: Sure...
[]>narrator: Her gaze grazes past you now.
[]>sophie: I am sure you concur that plenty a bean has been spilled already, so I will leave you to it.
[]>narrator: She motions towards the guard she's eyeing.
[]>sophie: She will accompany you to the warehouse. Instructions will be given. <mp>You will be safe.
[]>narrator: Still shaking from crying.
[]>narrator: Guard gives you a tissue.
[]>narrator: Clean up. <mp>Head out. <mp>Easy steps.<mp> Whatever.

[]>narrator{heather-emotion|invisible}: You get to ride shotgun in the SUV. With hands clenched between your thighs, you depart.
[]>narrator: It takes a while for her to say anything to you.
[]>guard{guard-emotion|neutral}: Fresh meat, eh?
[]>narrator: She has both hands on the steering wheel. Her shoulder holster grins at you.
[]>guard: Listen, I dunno where she picked you up or why you fill for that other chick now. But here's the rub.
[]>guard: You try anything funny, you're dead.
[]>guard: There ain't much spark in your eyes already, it'd be a shame to snuff the rest out too.
[]>narrator: You're tired. 7-segment display looks like [code][color=#ff0000]11:39PM[/color][/code].
[]>guard: We're doing a pickup, if you couldn't believe it.
[]>guard: You'll meet the girls, it'll be a great time.
[]>guard: When that's done, I'll send you on your merry way to your destination, and we'll probably meet again at home base... <mp>or your funeral, depending on how badly you fuck up.
[]>heather: ...
[]>guard: She said you're safe, I know. You're gonna be safe if you don't say a word to anyone. Ever. Anywhere.
[]>heather: ...
[]>guard: Just take the shit and go where we tell you to. You're gonna get money for train tickets.
[]>heather: ...
[]>guard: You really are a silent type. I like that.
[]>guard: Little meat.
[]>guard: ...
[]>narrator: With her not saying anything anymore, you try not to test your boundaries. The quaking in your chest is enough to make you zone out for the rest of the ride.

[]>narrator: You stop in front of an old warehouse. Your... Escort? Gets out and walks toward the gate. You keep your hands in your lap. She returns.
[]>narrator: The gate opens and you drive inside.
[]>narrator: A pristine array of stock footage-worthy palettes stack up to the ceiling. There's nowhere that catches your interest.
[]>narrator: You stop a few aisles down.

[]>guard{guard-emotion|neutral,heather-emotion|neutral}: Get out.
[]>narrator: You do.
[]>narrator: With an awkward reverse hand movement, you push the door shut. <mp>She <call:play_sfx,car_door>slams it.
[]>narrator: Nods her head down the aisle.
[]>guard: That's the girls.

[]>narrator{guard2-emotion|neutral}: You walk towards the group of women standing around a wooden crate. Their conversation quiets and their heads turn.
[]>narrator: Guard girl next to you hugs a few of them, greets them all- None by name.
[]>guard: So. This is Heather.
[]>guard2: Ohoho, new girl?
[]>narrator: That one has a raspy, airy voice.
[]>narrator: And a neck scar to match.
[]>guard: Yep. First run today.
[]>narrator: You briefly eye the other girls too. Most of them have visible scarring somewhere.
[]>narrator: Did they all end up here like you?
[]>narrator: The lustre of pistols and boot knives occasionally catch in the warm glow of the overhead lamps as well.
[]>guard2: New girl.
[]>narrator: Oh.
[]>guard2: Quit spacin' out.
[]>guard2: Cred?
[]>narrator: You don't give any look back. What is she talking about?
[]>guard2: What. <ap>Qualifies. <ap>You. <ap>To. <ap>Be. <ap>Here?
[]>narrator: You shrug.
[]>narrator: Neck-scar-girl turns to your... Handler?
[]>narrator: You really need some of their names.
[]>guard2: So what's she doing here, again?

[]>guard: Fuck if I know why she picked her.
[]>guard2: Hand-picked?
[]>guard: Apparently.
[]>guard2: Well. She'll have her reasons.
[]>guard: Anyways. Heather.
[]>narrator: You hint at turning toward her.
[]>narrator: She steps toward the crate at the center. Disregards you.
[]>guard: This one tells you where you need to go.
[]>narrator: Clipboard.
[]>guard: And this is said thing.
[]>narrator: Package. About 4 pounds.
[]>guard2: Anythin' else?
[]>guard: Nah.
[]>guard2: Good.
[]>narrator: Guard girl pats your shoulder.
[]>guard: Let's go.
[]>narrator: Package and clipboard in hand, you turn.
[]>guard: Enjoy your break, girlies.
[]>narrator{guard2-emotion|invisible}: She waves as you walk back. <mp>You follow in her steps. <mp>Small tippy taps make you match pace.
[]>heather: So...
[]>narrator: Her frown thunders down at you.
[]>heather: What's your name?
[]>guard: Why do you care?
[]>heather: Seems helpful.
[]>guard: Maybe. <ap>If you don't end up as dogfood before you get back... Maybe you'll learn.
[]>guard: Not my place to give out that info.

[]>narrator: You don't exchange any more words.
[]>narrator: Let out like a stray puppy. Then her guard takes off. <mp>The wind at the train station is surprisingly biting at times.
[]>narrator: Last train today to another city you've never been to before.
[]>narrator: You sleep like shit.
[]>narrator: The delivery the next day involves the most talking you've done since this entire thing started.
[]>narrator: A friendly hangout with someone churning though names as much as they do with partners- If what you chat about is true.
[]>narrator: You lament your very real relationship struggles, without mentioning how She killed Anna. The crush you've been nursing for months.
[]>narrator: If your world wasn't upside down and you met not as a drug mule but a friend, this might have had the potential to genuinely feel connected to another human being.
[]>narrator: But that's not where you or your life is.
[]>narrator: So with complete dissociation blanketing your brain, you say your goodbyes, get a small hug, and think about walking into oncoming traffic.
[]>narrator: ...
[]>narrator: As if you'd ever commit.
[]>narrator: Attached to the clipboard were instructions to return ASAP. <mp>So you do.

[]>sophie{guard-emotion|neutral,sophie-emotion|neutral,heather-emotion|neutral}: How did she do?
[]>guard: Nothing to report.
[]>sophie: My my. And my client reported positively too.
[]>sophie: You did well Heather, I'm proud of you.
[]>narrator: Your heart jumps a little at that.
[]>sophie: You've been so quiet. Is something bothering you?
[]>heather: ...Fine.
[]>sophie{sophie-emotion|annoyed}: Speak up.
[]>heather: Everything is fine.
[]>sophie{sophie-emotion|pity}: Heather. I care about your wellbeing here. So please do tell me when something is bothering you.
[]>heather: I will.
[]>sophie{sophie-emotion|neutral}: Good.
[]>heather: ...
[]>narrator: She doesn't dismiss you.
[]>narrator: Meaning: You are not to get up.
[]>narrator: The silence is nothing.
[]>narrator: At first.
[]>narrator: Your eyes briefly flutter to the wall behind Her.
[]>narrator: Is there new blood there?
[]>narrator: Were those tiles always this grimy?<lc>Probably.
[]>narrator{heather-emotion|sad}: Yet.<lc> Why is your life like this now?<lc>This is nothing.<lc>Worse than nothing.
[]>narrator: What did you even deliver.
[]>narrator: Why is She. So serene. In this.
[]>narrator: Are you gonna end up buried?
[]>narrator: Will you even see a funeral?
[]>narrator: Your hand still hurts.
[]>narrator: It will never be the same again.
[]>heather{heather-emotion|crying}: Please...
[]>sophie: ...
[]>heather: Please... Please just make this stop...
[]>heather:I want my old life back.
[]>narrator: Your forehead slumps down once more. Doesn't impact the tabletop with as much force.
[]>narrator: She doesn't get up this time.
[]>narrator{heather-emotion|sad}: You pull yourself back up after just a few sobs.

[]>narrator: She leans forward. Just a bit.
[]>sophie: If you promise to remain so well-behaved, I will let you sleep at home tonight. And your future outings will be even less precarious.
[]>heather: ...
[]>sophie: It is the best I can offer you.
[]>heather: ...
[]>sophie: It is for the best.
[]>sophie: And...
[]>sophie{heather-emotion|crying}: I might accompany you on future trips, if possible.
[]>narrator:The walk home is wrought with numerous crying and heaving panic attacks.

[]>narrator{heather-emotion|anger}:This is all too much. <mp>Nothing is real, nothing is fake, nothing is anything anymore.
[]>narrator:Barely inside, you slump down against your door as it closes.
[]>narrator{heather-emotion|crying}:Curled up upright fetal position.

[]>narrator: Your life is a haze.
[]>narrator: Existence itself is too heavy to bear.
[]>narrator: You make your body carry more of your burden.

[]>narrator: The notches of the boxcutter rap into this empty room.
[]>narrator: You rest it on your other arm.
[]>narrator:The first cut is always the most difficult one. Are you really about to cut into your skin? Is this was healthy people are supposed to do?
[]>narrator: Of course not.
[]>narrator: But this is no threshold for you.
[]>narrator: It is but the mere realization that you've been here before, and will probably be here again. Your heart sinking in perpetuity, with the tar of inevitability clinging to it.
[]>narrator: You probably cannot get better.
[]>narrator: But at least you know that this helps. <mp>Somehow.
[]>narrator: The endorphins flood your brain like a wave of syrup. The shame of not going deep enough follows soon after. You barely draw blood on this first one.
[]>narrator: You observe the small trickle. Pinhead-sized droplets oozing from the cut.
[]>narrator: You feel good.
[]>narrator: Fuck, you feel amazing.
[]>narrator: You keep going.
[]>narrator: As you begin to widen the bleeding area, you're no step closer to finding any answers to your predicament but you also just don't really care.
[]>narrator: You've been powerless since forever.
[]>narrator: Shallow upon shallow cuts layer themselves, digging away every layer of skin.
[]>narrator: And when your arm becomes too slippery from the bleeding, you descend upon your thighs.
[]>narrator: You make the blood run down both of your legs. However many cuts it takes to feel complete. <mp>Never too deep. <mp>Never deep enough.
[]>narrator: ...
[]>narrator: You once said you were clean.
[]>narrator: Yeah, right.
[]>narrator: Another letter greets your mailbox. Same instructions as yesterdy. 9 pm.

[]>narrator:You kill the time by rotting on the couch. <mp>Occasionally you unsuccessfully attempt to distract yourself with the few offline games on your PC.
[]>narrator:Your internet connection is dead.
[]>narrator:So is your landline now.
[]>narrator:There was no phone in your mailbox.
[]>narrator: Everything's gone.
[]>narrator:Hopefully you will be too, soon.

[]>narrator:When evening sets, you depart.
[]>narrator:Same dissociated footsteps as the last time.

[]>heather{heather-emotion|neutral,sophie-emotion|neutral}:You left my PC intact, you left evidence all over me with that letter and and...
[]>sophie: You mean the PC we got these RAM sticks from?
[]>narrator: She pulls out two RAM sticks that are the same make as yours.
[]>narrator: ...
[]>narrator: I even know that you had killed your time by replaying Half-Life a few times.
[]>heather: How the fuck...
[]>sophie: "Your" pc has been ship-of-theseus'ed thrice in the last week. It became a simulacrum.
[]>sophie{sophie-emotion|smug}: There is no "evidence" to speak of. <mp>Aside from the system logs [i]I[/i] kept to fuck with you.
[]>sophie:Oh, and don't think you will get to return there any time soon. From now on, you'll sleep in here.
[]>heather:In... Where?
[]>sophie{sophie-emotion|pity}:Why, yes. All this communiting must be so tiring. So I have graciously prepared your own apartment down here.

[]>narrator{sophie-emotion|neutral,heather-emotion|neutral}:She leads you down a few stories, somewhere into the basement. <lc>The amenities are surprisingly... available. This is less of a prison cell. Maybe a nordic prison cell? You saw a documentary on that once.
[]>narrator:Summer camp. <lc>It's like fucking summer camp all over. There's a few mugs, a dying lightbulb, and a fake window that hints at hypothetical trees beyond these walls.
[]>heather{heather-emotion|sad}:This is a sick fucking joke.
[]>narrator{sophie-emotion|invisible}:The door behind you closes.

[]>narrator{heather-emotion|neutral}: You are woken up to a grating buzzer ringing throughout your sleeping quarters. Being informed of the time of day is not among your privileges. Evidently however, it is... Action? Time again.
[]>narrator{sophie-emotion|neutral}: One of the guards escorts you to <call: set_background,sophie_office,2>Her office.
[]>narrator: She hands you a letter.
[]>narrator: Addressed not to you.
[]>narrator: You have trouble deciding with how much force to grip the letter.
[]>narrator{sophie-emotion|invisible}: When you step outside, the sun is half-set.

[]>narrator: Another night, another... <mp>Fuck this.
[]>narrator: Your life as a drug mule and now also general go-getter continues.
[]>narrator{guard-emotion|neutral,heather-emotion|neutral}: You know who accompanies you, even if you still don't know her name.
[]>narrator: She doesn't mention the cuts.
[]>narrator: As if anyone ever had.
